logic.notes: GLP-1 agonists require diabetes diagnosis
Insulin requires diabetes diagnosis
GLP-1 agonists require diabetes diagnosis and adult patient
Oncology drugs require active cancer diagnosis; contraindicated in pregnancy
Targeted oncology therapy requires active cancer and adult patient
Manual wheelchair requires mobility-limiting diagnosis or age 65+
Power wheelchair requires severe mobility limitation and adult patient
Upper endoscopy requires GI bleeding diagnosis or age 50+
Colonoscopy requires age 45+ or GI bleeding diagnosis
Cardiac catheterization requires chest pain or heart failure diagnosis
Echo requires cardiac diagnosis or age 65+
Knee arthroscopy requires osteoarthritis diagnosis; excluded if pregnancy
Joint injection requires arthritis diagnosis or age 50+
Liver transplant evaluation for decompensated cirrhosis MELD ≥15, HCC within Milan criteria, or acute liver failure
MUGA scan for cardiac evaluation in liver transplant candidates age 50+ or with cardiac risk factors
PFTs for liver transplant candidates with hepatopulmonary syndrome, portopulmonary HTN, or smoking history
Cancer screening endoscopy for liver transplant candidates age 50+ or with PSC/IBD risk factors
TIPS procedure for recurrent variceal bleeding or refractory ascites in Child-Pugh A/B cirrhosis - interventional radiology
Lactulose therapy for overt or minimal hepatic encephalopathy in cirrhosis patients - first-line treatment
Rifaximin therapy for recurrent hepatic encephalopathy with inadequate lactulose response - second-line treatment
CT angiography for HCC evaluation in cirrhosis patients with abnormal surveillance imaging - diagnostic workup
HCC surveillance ultrasound every 6 months for cirrhosis patients without active HCC
EGD surveillance for varices screening in new cirrhosis or established varices monitoring
Variceal band ligation for large varices or bleeding prevention/treatment in cirrhosis
Paracentesis for new-onset, refractory ascites or SBP evaluation in decompensated cirrhosis
Hepatitis C DAA therapy requires detectable HCV RNA, genotype testing, and absence of contraindications
Hepatitis B antiviral therapy for elevated HBV DNA/ALT, cirrhosis, or reactivation risk
HCV RNA monitoring during treatment, acute infection assessment, or response evaluation
HBV DNA monitoring for treatment response, inactive carrier surveillance, or reactivation risk
ICD/CRT-D requires HFrEF with EF ≤35%, optimal medical therapy ≥3 months, life expectancy >1 year
CRT requires HFrEF, QRS ≥150ms with LBBB, NYHA II-IV, optimal medical therapy
Entresto requires HFrEF with ACE inhibitor intolerance, NYHA II-IV, no angioedema history
Exercise stress testing requires cardiac symptoms or known CAD; age 18-85
Nuclear stress requires abnormal exercise stress or high pretest probability; limited to every 2 years
Stress echo for patients unable to exercise or with valvular disease; limited to every 2 years
Echocardiography requires cardiac diagnosis; limited to every 6 months unless clinical change
TEE requires specific indications: endocarditis, AF evaluation, stroke workup, or valve assessment
EP study/ablation requires symptomatic arrhythmia with failed antiarrhythmic therapy
Pacemaker requires symptomatic bradycardia or heart block with excluded reversible causes
IV amiodarone for hemodynamically unstable arrhythmias; contraindicated with thyroid/lung disease
Cardiac rehab requires qualifying cardiac event, physician referral, and medical stability
Intensive cardiac rehab for high-risk patients when standard rehab insufficient
Cardiac catheterization requires unstable angina, MI, known CAD, or high-risk stress test
PCI requires acute coronary syndrome or significant stenosis on catheterization
CABG requires multivessel disease, heart team evaluation, and surgical candidacy

logic.note: Botulinum toxin for chronic migraine with ≥15 headache days per month
Botulinum toxin for cervical dystonia with functional impairment
Botulinum toxin for blepharospasm or hemifacial spasm with visual impairment
Botulinum toxin for focal spasticity with functional impairment
Botulinum toxin for neurogenic detrusor overactivity refractory to anticholinergics
Disease-modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis
High-efficacy DMTs for highly active or rapidly evolving severe MS
Brain MRI with gadolinium for MS monitoring and disease activity assessment
High-dose corticosteroids for acute MS relapses with functional impairment
Plasma exchange for severe steroid-refractory MS relapses
Mechanical thrombectomy for acute large vessel occlusion stroke
IV thrombolysis (tPA) for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours
Carotid duplex ultrasound for stroke workup and carotid stenosis evaluation
Carotid endarterectomy for severe symptomatic carotid stenosis
EMG/NCS for evaluation of suspected neuromuscular disorders
Muscle biopsy for suspected inflammatory myopathy or muscular dystrophy
IVIG or plasma exchange for myasthenic crisis or severe neuromuscular junction disorders
Disease-modifying therapy for ALS (riluzole, edaravone)
Genetic testing for suspected hereditary neuromuscular disorders
Gene therapy or antisense oligonucleotides for genetic neuromuscular disorders
EEG for new onset seizure or refractory epilepsy evaluation
Video EEG monitoring for refractory epilepsy and surgical candidacy
Third-line antiepileptic drugs for refractory epilepsy
Epilepsy surgery for medically refractory focal epilepsy
Vagus nerve stimulator for refractory epilepsy not amenable to surgery
Bariatric surgery for morbid obesity with comorbidities and surgical candidacy documented weight loss attempts and completed evaluations with multidisciplinary team assessment

Anti-obesity medications for weight management with lifestyle intervention failure BMI ≥30 or BMI ≥27 with comorbidities after documented lifestyle modification trial using FDA-approved weight loss medications

Medical nutrition therapy for obesity management with registered dietitian counseling or metabolic syndrome with physician referral limited to 6 sessions per year using evidence-based nutrition interventions
Behavioral counseling for obesity and weight management with lifestyle modification support limited to 12 sessions per year using cognitive behavioral therapy techniques
CGM coverage for Type 1 diabetes with frequent hypoglycemia episodes requiring enhanced glucose monitoring and glycemic variability assessment
Insulin pump therapy for brittle diabetes management with glycemic variability and continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion
GLP-1 agonist therapy for Type 2 diabetes with obesity and cardiovascular benefits including weight reduction
HbA1c testing frequency limits for diabetes monitoring and glycemic control assessment with quarterly testing restrictions
DEXA bone density scan for osteoporosis screening and fracture risk assessment in women 65+ postmenopausal women 50-64 with risk factors or fracture history with dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry
Bisphosphonate therapy for osteoporosis treatment and fracture prevention with T-score ≤-2.5 or high fracture risk excluding esophageal disorders with oral antiresorptive agents
Denosumab therapy for severe osteoporosis with bisphosphonate intolerance or bisphosphonate intolerance with high fracture risk using RANKL inhibitor subcutaneous injection
Teriparatide therapy for severe osteoporosis with fractures and anabolic bone formation multiple fractures when antiresorptive therapy inadequate using recombinant human parathyroid hormone
Thyroid uptake and scan for hyperthyroidism evaluation and nodule assessment with radioiodine imaging
Radioactive iodine therapy for hyperthyroidism treatment and thyroid ablation with I-131 administration
Thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer or compressive goiter with surgical indications and endocrine surgery consultation

logic.notes: HMO small group: Brain MRI requires PA even with cancer diagnosis

_meta.note: Overrides general imaging rule for HMO small group plans

logic.notes: OSA surgery requires CPAP failure/intolerance with anatomic obstruction and surgical candidacy
Hypoglossal nerve stimulation requires CPAP intolerance, AHI 15-65, BMI <32, age ≥22
Sleep study requires sleep disorder symptoms with ESS ≥10; limited to annually
Home sleep testing for high probability OSA without comorbid cardiopulmonary disease
CPAP/BiPAP requires documented OSA with AHI ≥15 on sleep study
Spirometry requires respiratory symptoms or known lung disease; limited to every 6 months
Plethysmography requires abnormal spirometry and suspected restrictive disease
Asthma biologics require severe asthma with failed step 5 therapy and elevated IgE or eosinophils
Omalizumab requires allergic asthma with IgE 30-700 IU/mL and positive allergen testing
Mepolizumab requires eosinophilic asthma with ≥300 eosinophils and ≥2 exacerbations/year
Pulmonary rehab requires moderate-severe COPD or ILD with physician referral and stable condition
Home oxygen requires documented hypoxemia with O2 sat ≤88% or PaO2 ≤55 mmHg
Diagnostic bronchoscopy requires abnormal chest imaging and appropriate indication
Transbronchial biopsy requires tissue diagnosis need with accessible lesion and no bleeding risk
Therapeutic bronchoscopy for airway obstruction when surgical intervention not preferred

logic.note: Antimalarials require baseline eye exam and G6PD screening
SLE biologics require conventional therapy failure and severe manifestations
Immunosuppressants require disease severity justification and safety monitoring
Biologic DMARDs require failure of conventional DMARDs and active disease
TNF inhibitors require MTX failure and screening for infections/malignancy
JAK inhibitors require biologic failure, age <65, no CV/malignancy risk
Biologic infusions require specialized monitoring and facility
Injectable corticosteroids for acute gout when oral agents contraindicated
Urate-lowering therapy requires elevated uric acid and recurrent attacks
Pegloticase reserved for refractory gout with severe manifestations
Kidney transplant evaluation for stages 4-5 CKD or ESRD with transplant center referral and evaluation indicated excluding active malignancy or severe comorbidities
HLA typing and crossmatching for active transplant candidates or living donor evaluation with approved transplant listing and immunologic compatibility testing needed
Kidney transplant procedures for ESRD or stage 5 CKD with transplant center approval donor organ available and medically stable recipient
Post-transplant immunosuppressive medications for kidney transplant recipients with transplant center management and immunosuppression indicated excluding severe infections or malignancy
CKD monitoring frequency limits for stages 3-5 with nephrology consultation indicated and quarterly testing restrictions for metabolic panels
Advanced CKD management for stages 4-5 with progressive disease requiring nephrology management and GFR decline documentation with specialized monitoring
Dialysis preparation procedures for stage 5 CKD or ESRD with multidisciplinary education completed and dialysis preparation indicated
ACE inhibitor or ARB therapy for CKD with proteinuria hypertension or diabetic nephropathy with blood pressure above target and renoprotective therapy indicated
Hemodialysis procedures for ESRD or stage 5 CKD with functional dialysis access and nephrology supervision excluding active access site infections
Peritoneal dialysis procedures for ESRD or stage 5 CKD with completed home dialysis training adequate social support and peritoneal dialysis candidacy
Home dialysis services for ESRD with appropriate home environment patient and caregiver training completed and stable medical condition
Dialysis-related medications for mineral bone disorder hyperphosphatemia or secondary hyperparathyroidism with documented laboratory values supporting treatment
AV fistula creation for stages 4-5 CKD or ESRD with vascular mapping completed surgical candidacy and adequate vessel anatomy for dialysis access planning
AV graft placement for ESRD or stage 5 CKD when fistula not feasible or failed with vascular surgery consultation and graft placement indicated
Central venous catheter insertion for urgent dialysis access in ESRD or acute stage 5 CKD when immediate dialysis access needed and temporary access appropriate
Dialysis access maintenance and revision procedures for access dysfunction stenosis or thrombosis with abnormal surveillance and intervention indicated

logic.notes: EGD diagnostic requires appropriate GI symptoms or surveillance indication; limited annually unless acute bleeding
Therapeutic EGD dilation requires documented dysphagia with imaging-confirmed stricture or obstruction
ERCP diagnostic/therapeutic requires abnormal biliary/pancreatic imaging and appropriate indication
IBD biologic therapy requires moderate-severe disease with failed conventional therapy and negative TB screening
Ustekinumab biologic for Crohn's disease requires anti-TNF failure with moderate-severe disease
IBD surveillance colonoscopy screening every 1-2 years after 8 years of disease duration
EUS-FNA procedure requires cross-sectional imaging and inaccessible lesion needing tissue diagnosis
Therapeutic ERCP intervention requires abnormal MRCP/CT with planned intervention when surgery not preferred
Pancreatic duct ERCP therapy for recurrent pancreatitis with duct abnormality when surgery not indicated
Advanced colonoscopic resection technique for large lesions ≥20mm when endoscopically feasible
Therapeutic colonoscopy intervention for GI bleeding in hemodynamically stable patients
Colonoscopy screening at age 45+ for average risk, earlier for family history or IBD surveillance indication
Surveillance colonoscopy interval based on polyp histology, cancer history, or genetic syndrome

logic.note: ESWL for kidney stones 5-20mm with appropriate clinical criteria
Ureteroscopy with laser lithotripsy for ureteral and complex kidney stones
PCNL for large kidney stones >20mm and staghorn calculi
Comprehensive metabolic evaluation for recurrent stone formers
Medical therapy for stone prevention (thiazides, allopurinol, citrate)
Complex urodynamic studies for neurogenic bladder and complex incontinence
Intravesical botulinum toxin injection for refractory overactive bladder
Sling procedures for stress urinary incontinence
Artificial urinary sphincter placement for severe incontinence
Sacral neuromodulation for refractory overactive bladder and urinary retention
Periurethral bulking agent injection for mild stress incontinence
PSA screening for prostate cancer in average-risk men aged 50-75
Prostate biopsy for elevated PSA or abnormal digital rectal exam
MRI-guided prostate biopsy for prior negative biopsy or active surveillance
Genomic testing for prostate cancer risk stratification
Active surveillance protocol for very low and low-risk prostate cancer
PSMA PET imaging for high-risk or recurrent prostate cancer
Alpha-blocker therapy for moderate to severe BPH with lower urinary tract symptoms
5-alpha reductase inhibitor therapy for enlarged prostate with progression risk
TURP for medically refractory BPH with complications
Laser enucleation/vaporization for BPH in patients on anticoagulation
